item.title: A case study in population fluctuations: snowshoe hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska
item.description:
Introduction

Snowshoe hares experience population fluctuations approximately every 8-11 years1. This document explores the population dynamics of hares tagged in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska between 1998 and 2012. It shows how the abundance has changed, and compares the average weight of hares in the years of lowest and highest abundance.

Figure 1. Snowshoe hare, Lepus americanus. Photo Credit: National Park Service (source)

Figure 2. Location of Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, approximately 20 km southwest of Fairbanks, Alaska. Map Credit: Bonanza Creek LTER (source)

Initial Data Wrangling

This section contains the code used to read-in and manipulate the dataset provided by the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research Program for the subsequent visualizations and analyses.

Note: This dataset includes information about the number of hares tagged in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest. For the sake of this document, it will be assumed that the number of hares tagged translates directly to the size of the overall population.

# Attach Packages 
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(lubridate)
library(kableExtra)

# Read in data, initial wrangling to select necessary columns
hare <- read_csv("showshoe_lter.csv") %>% 
  select(date, sex, age, weight, b_key, grid) %>% 
  mutate(date = mdy(date),
         year = year(date),
         month = month(date))


# Create data frame to see population change over time
yearly_timeline <- hare %>%
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(
    count = n(),
    avg_wt = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE))

Visualization

Snowshoe hares experience population fluctuations every 8-11 years1. Figure 1 illustrates this concept by showing the annual abundances of hares tagged in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest from 1998-2012. Populations were high in 1999 (nearly 400 hares tagged), but decreased drastically to a low of 29 in 2002. Following this low, the population gradually increased even higher - by 2009, there were 439 hares taggged.

# Use ggplot to create a graph showing changes in annual abundance
ggplot(data = yearly_timeline) + # use data frame from previous tab
  geom_path(aes(x = year, y = count), color = "red")+ 
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1998, 2012), # set limits to x and y axis
                     breaks = c(1998:2012), 
                     expand = c(0,.5)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 500), 
                     expand = c(0,0))+
  labs( # add reader-friendly labels
    y = "Number of hares trapped",
    x = "year") +
  theme_classic() # simple theme

Figure 3. Annual abundances of tagged snowshoe hares in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest from 1998 to 2012.

Statistical Comparison

# Data frame to compare just the weights
weight <- hare %>% 
  filter(year %in% c(2002,2009)) %>% 
  select(year, weight)

# Look at the data to see how they are distributed
# ggplot(data = weight, aes(x = weight)) +
#  geom_histogram()+
#  facet_wrap(~year, scales = "free") 

# Lack of data (because lack of hares) in 2002 - not as nicely distributed but still probably OK
# ggplot(data = weight, aes(sample = weight)) + 
#  geom_qq()+
#  facet_wrap(~year)

#Since the majority seem normal, will still do a two-sample t-test to compare means.
weight_2002 <- weight %>% 
  filter(year == "2002")
weight_2009 <- weight %>% 
  filter(year == "2009")

weight_t <- t.test(weight_2009$weight, weight_2002$weight)

# Alternative for non-parametric data would be the Mann-Whitney U (just try out of curiosity) - compares medians
weight_rank <- wilcox.test(weight_2002$weight, weight_2009$weight)

# Both are insignificant results - meaning that there isn't a significant difference in the means or medians

# Create data frame "diff" to compare lowest abundance (2002) to highest (2009)
diff <- hare %>% 
  filter(year %in% c(2002, 2009)) %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(
    "Abundance" = n(),
    "Average Weight (g)" = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  pivot_longer("Abundance":"Average Weight (g)", 
               names_to = "metric", 
               values_to = "value") %>% 
  pivot_wider(id_cols = metric, 
              names_from = year, 
              values_from = value) %>% 
  rename(y2002 = "2002") %>%  # Rename for friendlier calculations in subsequent steps
  rename(y2009 = "2009") %>% 
  mutate(pct_diff = round(((y2009-y2002)/y2002)*100, 1)) %>% # calculate percent difference
  mutate(pct_diff = paste(pct_diff, "%", sep = "")) %>% # add "%" to those calculated values
  mutate_if(is.numeric, format, digits = 1, nsmall = 0) # restrict number of decimal places



# Use kableExtra to make a nicely-formatted table 
kable(diff, col.names = c("", "2002", "2009", "Percent Increase")) %>%
        kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), 
                full_width = F) %>% 
add_header_above(c("Table 1: Extreme fluctuations in the snowshoe hare population in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska" = 4))
Table 1: Extreme fluctuations in the snowshoe hare population in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest, Alaska
2002 2009 Percent Increase
Abundance 38 491 1192.1%
Average Weight (g) 1202 1338 11.3%

Examining the abundance of hares over time showed that the population declined to an extreme low in 2002, but increased by 1192% to a new peak in 2009 (Figure 1, Table 1). The average weight of the hares increased slightly from 2002 to 2009 (11%), but the difference is insignificant (two sample t-test, t(36.28) = 1.9, p = 0.066).

Citations and Additional Exploratory Code

  1. Kielland K., F. S. Chapin, R. W. Ruess. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14. Dataset accessed 1/30/2020.
# Exploratory Code Not Used for Final Document 
# Examine and visualize monthly fluctuations in hare abundance
monthly_timeline <- hare %>%
  group_by(month) %>% 
  summarize(
    count = n(),
    avg_wt = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(data = monthly_timeline) +
  geom_point(aes(x = month, y = count)) +
  geom_line(aes(x = month, y = avg_wt))

# What if we follow weights of individual hares through time?
individual <- hare %>% 
  filter(!is.na(weight), !is.na(b_key)) %>% 
  group_by(b_key) %>% 
  summarize(
    count = n() # There are 9 that have been seen and weighed at least 15x
  ) %>% 
  arrange(-count) %>% 
  head(9) 

weights <- hare %>% 
  filter(b_key %in% individual$b_key & !is.na(weight)) %>% 
  mutate(id = as.factor(b_key))

ggplot(data = weights) +
  geom_path(aes(x = date, y = weight, color = id))

paletteer, tsibble, feasts, fable, fabletools, forecast, and mapview

item.title: Examining global environmental data with principal component analysis
item.description:
Introduction

This document explores the relationship between various environmental variables for 224 different countries. It will use principal component analysis to illustrate how characteristics like elevation, rainfall, and amount of cropland relate to each other at global scale.

About the data: this document uses data compiled and provided by @zanter_venter, who synthesized country-level statistics using the Google Earth Engine. Data can be found here.

Data Analysis

# Attach packages
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(ggfortify)

# Read in the world environment data:
world_data <- read_csv("world_env_vars.csv") %>% 
  select(elevation, cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, rain_mean_annual, temp_mean_annual, cloudiness) %>% 
  rename("Elevation" = elevation, # Rename variables for plot label friendliness later
         "Cropland Cover" = cropland_cover,
         "Tree Canopy Cover" = tree_canopy_cover,
         "Mean Annual Rainfall" = rain_mean_annual,
         "Mean Annual Temperature" = temp_mean_annual,
         "Cloudiness" = cloudiness)

# Evaluate missing data situation
# summary(world_data)

# None of the chosen variables have too many NAs (11 is max) compared to data set - will drop those
world_data <- world_data %>% 
  drop_na()

# PConduct pca and save, scale = TRUE to convert to similar scales
world_pca <- prcomp(world_data, scale = TRUE)

# Use ggfortify to make a biplot
autoplot(world_pca,
         colour = NA,
         loadings.colour = "forestgreen", # change color of eigenvectors
         loadings.label = TRUE, 
         loadings.label.size = 3,
         loadings.label.colour = "black",
         loadings.label.repel = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal()+
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-0.2, 0.2), expand = c(0,0)) + # set limits to scale of x and y axis
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(-0.2, 0.2), expand = c(0,0))

Figure 1. Biplot resulting from principal component anlaysis conducted on world environmental data. Green arrows indicate strength and relationship of variables labeled.

Summary

  • Elevation and cropland cover are highly positively correlated with each other
  • Mean annual temperature is negatively correlated with elevation and cropland cover
  • Mean annual rainfall, canopy cover, and cloudiness are positively correllated with each other and minimally correlated with the other three variables

item.title: Population characteristics of the Pacific giant salamander in old growth vs clear cut forests
item.description:
Introduction

Amphibian populations have been declining for over half a century1, with more than 32% of global populations currently threatened2. Habitat loss and fragmentation are among the biggest threats to these fragile populations, which require particular temperatures and levels of moisture to survive3. Clear-cut logging, in particular, has been shown to increase sedimentation in streams, which negatively impacts larval amphibians3. Monitoring efforts have been implemented to assess how activities like clear-cutting affect salmonid populations, including the Aquatic Vertebrate Population Study within the H.J. Andrews Forest Long Term Ecological Research Program (HJA LTER), which monitors the threatened Pacific giant salamander (Dicamptodon tenebrosus) among other species. Here, we examine the distribution of Pacific giant salamanders in a section of forest that was clear-cut for logging in 1963 compared to a nearby 500 year old coniferous forest in Mack Creek, Oregon. Restoration efforts are sometimes used to attempt to convert habitats from a degraded state back to their pre-disturbance condition, typically by creating pools or increasing habitat complexity4. Understanding how the distribution of Pacific giant salamanders changes in different habitats can help guide restoration efforts.

Figure 1. Pacific giant salamander, Dicamptodon tenebrosus. Photographer: Joel Sartore, National Geographic Photographer (source)

Figure 2. Video of Pacific giant salamander. These are some of the only amphibians known to make vocalizations. Provided by YouTube user: MFWestphal (source)

Data and Methods

As part of an effort to monitor population trends of aquatic vertebrates in the H.J. Andrews Experimental Forest, data on annual abundances, weights, forest section location, and habitat preferences of the Pacific giant salamander have been collected by researchers with the Andrews Forest Long Term Ecological research site since 19935. Mack Creek runs through sections of both old growth and historically clear-cut forest and provides three primary types of habitat for aquatic organisms (pools, side-channels, and cascades). 150m stretches of the creek are divided into contiguous 50m sections, which were netted at each end. Observations for aquatic vertebrates were acquired via two-pass electrofishing, followed by subsequent measurement of body dimensions and weight for all captured individuals.

We compared annual abundances since 1993, and habitat preferences and weight differences in 2017 for Pacific giant salamanders in old growth and clear cut sections of forest. We used a Chi-square test to assess salamander habitat preferences within forest sections, a two-sample t-test test to compare mean weights by forest section, and a one-way ANOVA to compare mean weights of salamanders across the three primary habitat types. For all statistical tests, we used a significance level of \(\alpha\) = 0.05. All data preparation and analyses were completed using R software (version 3.6.1) and RStudio (version 1.2.5001).

Figure 3. Map of H. J. Andrews Experimental Forest with associated streams. Streams are depicted as blue lines and sample locations as green circles. This report focuses on salamanders found in Mack Creek. Picture credit: Sashka Warner. (source)

Results

Pacific giant salamander abundance over time

Trends in Pacific giant salamander abundance were compared for the clear cut and old growth sections of Mack Creek from 1993 to 2017 (Figure 4). Throughout 1993-2017, Pacifc giant salamander abundances observed in sections of old growth forest were consistently higher than in historically clear-cut sections, with exceptions to this trend in 1994 and 2014-2017. Both populations show a marked increase in abundance following 2001 and 2014, as well as a sharp decline in 2011. Overall, populations of salamanders increased from 1993 to 2017 by 154% in the old growth section, and 192% in the clear cut section.

Figure 4. Annual abundances of the Pacific giant salamander in two standard reaches of Mack Creek in the H. J. Andrews Experimental Forest from 1993 -2017. Salamanders were counted in a reach running through a section of old growth forest (blue line) and a section of historically clear-cut forest (red line).

Salamander habitat preference within old growth vs clear cut forest sections

Table 1: Proportions of giant salamanders
in different channel classifications
observed in two sections of Mack Creek
Clear Cut Old Growth
Cascade 247 (67.1%) 201 (62.8%)
Pool 31 (8.4%) 45 (14.1%)
Side-Channel 90 (24.5%) 74 (23.1%)

Channels that make up Pacific giant salamander habitat are often classified into three different areas: cascades, pools, and side channels. Proportions of salamanders in each channel classification were compared for the old growth and clear cut sections of Mack Creek (Table 1).

There is not a significant effect of forest section (old growth or clear cut) on where salamanders are found in the channel (\(\chi\)2(2) = 5.54, p = 0.06). There are similar proportions of salamanders found in each of the three channel classifications in both the clear-cut and old growth sections of forest (Table 1).

Comparison of salamander weight by forest section and channel classification

In addition to abundance, examining salamander weight can yield more information about the size distribution of the populations in the different forest sections and channel classifications.

There was no significant difference in mean salamander weight in 2017 for the old growth compared to the clear cut section of forest (two sample t-test, t(692.79) = -1.67, p = 0.096). Thus, weight information was combined for the two sections to examine size distributions across the diffferent channel classifications (Figure 5).

Figure 5. Distributions for Giant Pacific Salamander mass (g) are displayed (violins) for habitat type, pooled for old growth and clear cut sections of forest. Mean masses (black dots) \(\pm\) standard error (error bars) are displayed for each habitat type.

Mean weights of Pacific giant salamanders did differ significantly between pools and side channels (one-way ANOVA with post-hoc Tukey’s HSD: F\(_{2,684}\) = 4.22, p = 0.015). Mean weights for individuals from cascades did not differ significantly from the other two habitat types (Figure 5). The average weight for populations residing in pools (9.3 \(\pm\) 1.56 g) was 63.79% more than that of populations observed in side-channels (5.68 \(\pm\) 0.65 g). Due to large within group variation of salamander weights in each habitat type, an alternative metric – population medians, for instance – may lend to a more meaningful and accurate comparison across these groups. This could be achieved by using a rank-based test, such as a Mann-Whitney U test.

Summary

  • From 1993-2017, overall Pacific giant salamander abundances increased in both old growth and historically clear cut sections of forest, by 154% and 192% respectively (Figure 4).
  • Forest section (old growth vs clear cut) did not significantly affect the habitat type (pool, cascade, or side-channel) in which salamnders were found (Table 1).
  • There is no significant difference in mean salamander weight in 2017 for the old growth compared to the clear cut section of forest.
  • In 2017, the mean weight of salamanders residing in pools was significantly greater than that of populations in side channels (Figure 5).

References

  1. Houlahan, J., et al. “Quantitative evidence for global amphibian population declines.” Nature 404 (2000): 752-755.

  2. Stuart, S. N., et al. “Status and trends of amphibian declines and extinctions worldwide.” Science 306 (2004): 1783-1786.

  3. Johnston, B. and Frid, L. “Clearcut logging restricts the movements of terrestrial Pacific giant salamanders (Dicamptodon tenebrosus Good)” Canadian Journal of Zoology 80 (2011): 2170-2177.

  4. IDK WHICH ONE IT IS CAUSE YOU CANT GET ACCESS OFF CAMPUS WHICH IS DUMB SO GUESS ILLL DO IT TOMORROW

  5. Gregory S. V. 2016. Aquatic Vertebrate Population Study in Mack Creek, Andrews Experimental Forest, 1987 to present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/5de64af9c11579266ef20da2ff32f702. Dataset accessed 11/19/2019.

item.title: Spiny lobster size and abundance along the Santa Barbara coast
item.description:
Introduction

Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) have been established along the California coast to protect coastal species and their habitat through regulation of fishing and other potentially harmful human activities1. Monitoring efforts have been implemented to assess the effectiveness of these MPAs by comparing population characteristics of species inside and outside of the protected areas2. One such effort, undertaken by the Santa Barbara Coastal Long Term Ecological Research (SBC LTER) program, conducts yearly monitoring of kelp forest species in the Santa Barbara Channel inside and outside of MPAs. Within the Santa Barbara Channel, the California Spiny Lobster (Panulirus interruptus) is currently a species of interest, as it provides a lucrative fishery but also serves an important role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems through predation of sea urchins3. Without predatory regulation, sea urchins can reach abundances high enough to decimate kelp populations and induce unfavorable ecosystem shifts from kelp forests to urchin barrens4. Excessive fishing of other species of lobster has been implicated in causing subsequent overgrazing of macroalgal communities by sea urchins5, 6. Here, we assess impacts of fishing pressure on population characteristics of the California Spiny lobster from 2012-2018.

Figure 1: California Spiny Lobster, Panulirus interruptus. Photographer: Joel Sartore, National Geographic Photographer (source)

Data and methods

Data for California spiny lobster abundance and size were collected and provided by researchers with the Santa Barbara Coastal Long-Term Ecological Research Program (SBC LTER)7. Divers collected annual estimates from 2012-2018 at five long-term kelp forest sites. Two sites (Naples and Isla Vista) are located in designated MPAs, which were created on 2012-01-01. The other three sites (Mohawk Reef, Carpinteria, and Arroyo Quemado) are located in unprotected areas. Estimates were collected annually in late summer, before the start of the fishing season, by counting lobsters to quantify abundance and visually estimating the carapace length (mm) for size information across a 40-meter transect at the five sites.

Changes in annual lobster abundance over time were examined for each site by comparing the total lobster count for each year from 2012-2018. Size distributions were examined by comparing the size composition (mm) of the lobsters measured at each site in 2012 and in 2018. Mean lobster size was compared for lobsters measured in MPAs versus unprotected waters in 2012 and in 2018 using two-sample t-tests (\(\alpha\) = 0.5 throughout). For more information on site and data collection methods, see metadata.

All data preparation and analyses were completed using R software (version 3.6.1) and RStudio (version 1.2.5001).

Results

Trends in annual lobster abundance following MPA creation in 2012

The Isla Vista and Naples sites were declared MPAs in 2012, effectively eliminating fishing pressure for spiny lobsters in those areas. The trends in total annual lobster abundance for those two sites, as well as the three other unprotected sites, were compared for 2012-2018 (Fig. 2).

Figure 2. Total annual abundance of CA spiny lobsters for 5 sites in the Santa Barbara Channel from 2012 to 2018. Solid lines indicate sites within marine protected areas (Isla Vista and Naples) and dashed lines indicate sites in unprotected areas (Carpinteria, Mohawk, and Arroyo Quemado).

All sites have similar annual lobster abundance in 2012 and show an overall increase by 2018, but the two sites in Marine Protected Areas (Isla Vista and Naples) show a much greater increase than the sites in unprotected areas (Arroyo Quemado, Carpinteria, and Mohawk). From 2012 to 2018, annual lobster abundance at the Isla Vista and Naples sites increased by 3538% and 4866%, respectively. Percent increases in annual abundance were much smaller at the unprotected sites: though Carpinteria showed a drastic increase from 2015-2017, the overall increase in annual abundance was an order of magnitude smaller than the MPA sites (339%), and the other unprotected sites had even smaller changes at 42% and 98% (Arroyo Quemado and Mohawk, respectively).

Shifts in lobster size distributions from 2012 to 2018

Figure 3. Size distributions of the California Spiny Lobster at 5 sites in the Santa Barbara Channel (Naples and Isla Vista = within MPA; Mohawk, Arroyo Quemado, and Carpinteria = outside of MPA) in 2012 (red) and 2018 (blue). Sizes are measured as carapace length in mm.

Both sites within MPAs (Naples and Isla Vista) showed increases in lobster size distribution from 2012 to 2018 (Fig. 3). Size distributions of lobsters in the non-MPA sites (Mohawk reef, Carpinteria, and Arroyo Quemado) appear relatively similar in both 2012 and 2018.

Statistical comparisons for CA spiny lobster monitoring efforts

Immediately following establishment of the MPAs in 2012, mean lobster size at sites inside MPAs was significantly different from that observed for lobsters in unprotected waters (two-sample t-test, t(42.09) = -3.25, p = 0.002), with lobsters measured inside MPAs roughly 10% smaller (Table 1). By 2018, mean lobster size inside MPAs still differed significantly from unprotected waters (two-sample t-test, t(1239.51) = 7.31, p < 0.001), however it was roughly 5% greater in the MPA sites.

Lobster size inside MPA sites increased significantly by an average of 15% from 2012 to 2018 (two-sample t-test, t(32.5) = -4.69, p < 0.001)), while lobsters observed outside of MPAs showed a marginal non-significant decrease in mean size over the same time period (two-sample t-test, t(296.01) = 1.33, p = 0.18).

Table 1. California Spiny Lobster size statistics for monitoring efforts inside and outside of MPAs in the Santa Barbara Channel for 2012 and 2018.
Protection Mean Size (mm) Standard Deviation Sample Size
2012
MPA 67.37500 12.15425 32
Non-MPA 74.92462 12.41412 199
2018
MPA 77.56672 11.70341 1244
Non-MPA 73.61996 10.09438 561

Summary

  • Lobster abundances have increased from 2012 to 2018, with sites in MPAs showing much greater proportional increases than sites in unprotected areas (Fig. 2)
  • Size of lobsters in marine protected areas has increased from 2012 to 2018 (Fig. 3)
  • There is a significant difference in the size of lobsters in MPAs compared to unprotected waters (Table 1)

References

  1. “California Marine Protected Areas (MPAs)”. California Department of Fish and Wildlife, State of California, 2019. https://www.wildlife.ca.gov/Conservation/Marine/MPAs

  2. “MPA Monitoring.” California MPAs. http://californiampas.org/mpa-monitoring

  3. Tegner, M. J., and L. A. Levin. “Spiny lobsters and sea urchins: analysis of a predator-prey interaction.” Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology 73.2 (1983): 125-150.

  4. Ling, S. D., et al. “Global regime shift dynamics of catastrophic sea urchin overgrazing.” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences 370.1659 (2015): 20130269.

  5. Breen, P. A., and K. H. Mann. “Changing lobster abundance and the destruction of kelp beds by sea urchins.” Marine Biology 34.2 (1976): 137-142.

  6. Wharton, W. G., and K. H. Mann. “Relationship between destructive grazing by the sea urchin, Strongylocentrotus droebachiensis, and the abundance of American lobster, Homarus americanus, on the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia.” Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences 38.11 (1981): 1339-1349.

  7. Reed D. 2019. SBC LTER: Reef: Abundance, size and fishing effort for California Spiny Lobster (Panulirus interruptus), ongoing since 2012. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/a593a675d644fdefb736750b291579a0. Dataset accessed 11/14/2019.

item.title: Using time series data to explore steelhead passage across the Bonneville Dam
item.description:
Introduction

Steelhead are a fascinating group of fishes. They are the same species as freshwater rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), but exhibit the salmon-esque behavior of swimming upstream from the ocean to spawn in the rivers where they were born. Interestingly, some even return back to the ocean after spawning - something salmon don’t even do! Monitoring populations of these special fish is important as they face increased threats due to climate change. This document explores time series data of the passage of steelhead across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon from 1940-2019.

For an interesting read on the hot debate of if a steelhead should be considered a salmon or trout, check out this article.

Figure 1. Video of Bonneville Dam Fish Ladder. Provided by YouTube user: Pacific NW (source)

Data was retrieved from Columbia Basin Research DART (Data Access in Real Time), affiliated with the University of Washington. Counts are reported for fish crossing the Bonneville Dam fish ladder each day, either through live counts or video observations1. Data can be accessed here.

Initial setup & data wrangling

# Attach necessary packages
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)
library(janitor)
library(paletteer)
library(tsibble)
library(fable)
library(fabletools)
library(feasts)

# Read in data, clean up a bit!
fish <- read_csv("cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv") %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  mutate(day_month = mm_dd) %>%  # R doesn't love the mm-dd naming
  unite("date", "year":"mm_dd", sep = "-") %>%  # Combine year and month-day column
  mutate(date = ydm(date),
         year = year(date),
         month = month(date, label = TRUE),
         year_month = yearmonth(date)) %>%  #yearmonth class important for ts seasonplot
  filter(year %in% c(1940:2019)) # only observations from 1940-2019


# Create a subset totaling the number of fish counted each month
fish_month <- fish %>%
  group_by(year_month) %>% 
  summarize(total = sum(value, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  mutate(year = year(year_month),
         month = month(year_month, label = TRUE),
         fish = "steelhead")

# Coerce the fish_month data to a tsibble, which is friendlier for working with time series data
fish_ts <- as_tsibble(fish_month, key = fish, index = year_month)

# Look at it!
#autoplot(fish_ts)
#gg_subseries(fish_ts)

Exploring time series of steelhead passage: daily, monthly, and annually

Counts of the number of steelhead crossing the Bonneville Dam each day show potential seasonality in fluctuations of the population (Fig. 2). There seems to be significant variation between years, as well as a general increasing trend between 1940 and 2019. This section will examine these trends more closely.

# Basic plot of daily time series data
ggplot(data = fish) +
  geom_point(aes(x = date, y = value, color = year), 
             show.legend = FALSE) +
  theme_classic() +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = "Number of steelhead counted per day") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 35000), expand = c(0,0)) + # set y axis limits
  scale_color_paletteer_c("ggthemes::Blue")

Figure 2. Time series data of steelhead crossings for the Bonneville Dam from 1940-2019.

Closer examination reveals consistent seasonality in the timing of steelhead passage (Fig. 3) The highest number of steelhead counted is typically in the late summer months, usually around August, and has not shifted much between 1940 and 2019.

# Create a season plot of a subset of the data to examine shift in the timing of fish passage
ggplot(data = fish_month %>% filter(year %in% c(1940, 1960,  1980, 2000, 2019)), aes(x = month, y = total, group = year)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = year), show.legend = FALSE) +
  facet_wrap(~ year, 
             ncol = 1,  
             scales = "free",
             strip.position = "right")+
  labs(x = NULL,
       y = "number of steelhead counted each month")+
  scale_color_paletteer_c("ggthemes::Blue")+
  theme_classic()

Figure 3. Timing of steelhead passage across the Bonneville Dam in 1940, 1960, 1980, 2000, 2019.

Examining monthly counts for all years confirms the consistency in this timing (Fig. 4) but also highlights the interannual variation in the size of the population. The population peaks in late summer each year, but at very differrent levels.

# Use gg_season to make a more traditional season-plot
gg_season(fish_ts) + 
  labs(x = NULL,
       y = "number of steelhead counted") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 250000), expand = c(0,0)) +
  theme_classic()+
  scale_color_paletteer_c("ggthemes::Blue", direction = 1,
                          labels = c("1940", "1960", "1980", "2000", "2019"))

Figure 4. Passage of steelhead across the Bonneville Dam. Shades of blue transition from light to dark over time - early years (1940s) are shown in light blue, and later years (2010s) in darker blues.

There is significant interannual variability in the number of steelhead crossing the dam, as seen by the many peaks and troughs (Fig. 5 solid line), however this variability also follows a larger trend: the population saw significant increases in the late 1990s and early 2000s, but has since began to decline (Fig 5 dashed line and shaded area).

fish_year <- fish_ts %>% 
  index_by(annual = ~year(.)) %>% 
  summarize(
    avg_amount = mean(total))

ggplot(data = fish_year, aes(x = annual, y = avg_amount)) +
  geom_line(color = "steelblue4") +
  geom_smooth(color = "steelblue4",
              size = 0.2,
              linetype = "dashed",
              fill = "steelblue3",
              alpha = 0.2) +
  theme_classic() +
  labs(x = NULL,
       y = "annual number of steelhead")

Figure 5. Annual passage of steelhead across the Bonneville Dam (solid line), overall trend using loess smoothing (dashed line), with 95% confidence intervals (shaded area).

Citations

  1. Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text
